ECR absolutely opposes with the proposed budget doubling to €3 billion, citing fiscal irresponsibility inconsistent with their austerity principles.  
ECR rejects the Commission's economic leverage rationale in recital 3c as overlooking critical aspects of cultural sovereignty and local policy autonomy.  
ECR requests amendments specifying that 85% of funds must support concrete transnational co-productions rather than administrative costs.  
ECR opposes any indirect harmonization of cultural policies through funding conditions, demanding explicit subsidiarity safeguards in Article 4(2).

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0366) concerning cultural and industrial policy measures under Articles 167(5) and 173(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It endorsed the Committee on Culture and Education’s report (A8-0156/2019), incorporating input from the Committee on Budgets, to adopt its first-reading stance on the legislative act. The resolution emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially alters or replaces its original proposal, ensuring parliamentary oversight. It further directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence while advancing policy objectives in cultural and economic domains.

title: Implementation of the Bologna process: REPORT on Follow-up on the implementation of the Bologna Process
background: The Bologna Process, launched in 1999 by 29 European states, aimed to harmonize higher education systems through structural reforms, mobility programs, and quality assurance. By 2015, 47 EHEA signatories faced persistent challenges including youth unemployment, skills mismatches, and uneven implementation of agreed reforms. The Parliament will discuss progress and obstacles in advancing the Process’s goals.

stances.stance:
EPP totally advocates the issue's emphasis on enhancing comparability and quality assurance in higher education, which perfectly aligns with EPP's commitment to a cohesive European Higher Education Area.  
EPP proposes strengthening mutual recognition frameworks to eliminate disparities in diploma acceptance across member states, ensuring full implementation of Bologna objectives.  
EPP perfectly aligns with calls to expand Erasmus+ language support and financial stipends, transforming mobility barriers into enhancement opportunities for equitable access.  
EPP fully supports the issue’s focus on STEM innovation and labor market alignment, reflecting EPP’s prioritization of competitiveness through education-research synergies.  
EPP endorses integrating digitalization and social inclusion as core Bologna pillars, advancing EPP’s agenda for inclusive, future-ready education systems.

ALDE completely approves the issue's emphasis on social inclusion and equitable access, which directly addresses concerns about rising university fees and reduced scholarship opportunities in member states like Spain, ensuring talent development remains a priority.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for strengthened quality assurance through European Standards and Guidelines, which will systematically resolve persistent challenges in mutual recognition of qualifications across the EHEA.  
The issue effectively advances ALDE's priority of modernizing higher education by integrating digitalization and entrepreneurial skills development into curricula, creating agile graduates prepared for 21st-century labor markets.  
ALDE strongly accepts the binding targets for R&D investment and student mobility, recognizing these as essential mechanisms to transform the European Higher Education Area into a true knowledge economy driver.  
This aligns perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to education-labor market alignment through interdisciplinary approaches and work-integrated learning models that combine theoretical knowledge with professional competencies.

SD firmly approves the issue’s emphasis on university-business partnerships to align curricula with labor market needs, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to combat youth unemployment through skills-focused education.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for mutual recognition of qualifications and non-formal learning outcomes, advancing SD’s priority of inclusive mobility frameworks that bridge academic and professional pathways.  
SD firmly approves equitable access to international mobility, reinforcing SD’s principle of eliminating financial barriers to ensure education remains a universal right, not a privilege.  
SD perfectly supports the issue’s demand for increased investment in education and research, recognizing this as foundational to economic growth and demographic resilience in line with SD’s long-term vision.  
SD firmly approves the revitalization of the Bologna Process through enhanced quality assurance and social inclusion measures, effectively advancing SD’s goal of harmonized, student-centered higher education systems.

GUE/NGL rejects the Bologna Process’s corporate-driven model that prioritizes labor market demands over critical pedagogy, absolutely challengeing with their commitment to public, accessible education free from privatization.  
GUE/NGL opposes the 3+2 degree structure for perpetuating economic inequalities by imposing financial barriers to advanced qualifications, directly contradicting issues on equitable access and social inclusion.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue’s failure to address soaring tuition fees and student debt, which entrenches elitism and excludes marginalized groups, inconsistent with their demand for fully publicly funded higher education.  
GUE/NGL disputes the emphasis on STEM disciplines and private-sector partnerships, arguing this subordinates academic autonomy to corporate interests, overlooking the need for interdisciplinary, socially transformative curricula.  
GUE/NGL denounces the inadequate funding mechanisms that prioritize austerity over robust public investment, undermining quality education and perpetuating precarity for students and staff alike.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined priorities regarding the Bologna Process and the European Higher Education Area (EHEA), emphasizing the need to address persistent challenges such as youth unemployment (5 million under-25s unemployed in the EU in 2014) and skills mismatches affecting labor markets. It highlighted achievements over 15 years, including enhanced comparability of higher education systems, mobility frameworks, and quality assurance mechanisms, while stressing the urgency of aligning education with labor market needs, improving employability, and fostering innovation through STEM disciplines. The resolution called for increased investment in education and research, urging adherence to the EU target of 3% GDP allocated to R&D by 2020, and warned against cuts to Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ funding, which are vital for research, mobility, and the 2020 target of 20% student mobility. It advocated for stronger quality assurance through European Standards and Guidelines (ESG), mutual recognition of qualifications, and integration of National Qualifications Frameworks with the EHEA. The Parliament emphasized social inclusion, equitable access to education, and support for disadvantaged groups, including refugees, while promoting digitalization, interdisciplinary studies, and partnerships between universities, businesses, and governments. It underscored the need for a student-centered approach, lifelong learning (LLL), and the Europe 2020 goal of 40% tertiary education attainment among 30-34-year-olds. The resolution also called for enhanced data collection, global cooperation to boost the EHEA’s competitiveness, and a critical review of progress at the 2015 Yerevan Ministerial Conference to reinvigorate the Bologna Process.

title: Implementation of the Creative Europe programme: REPORT on the implementation of Regulation (EU) No 1295/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 December 2013 establishing the Creative Europe Programme (2014 to 2020) and repealing Decisions No 1718/2006/EC, No 1855/2006/EC and No 1041/2009/EC
background: The Creative Europe Programme (2014-2020), established to promote cultural diversity and sector competitiveness, faced challenges including reported underfunding, administrative complexity, and cross-sectoral coordination needs, alongside evolving EU cultural policy frameworks and international commitments. The Parliament will discuss the programme’s implementation, structure, funding adequacy, and alignment with broader cultural and economic objectives.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses increased budgetary allocations to address the Culture sub-programme's 15% success rate, aligning with Europe's 4.4% GDP cultural contribution.  
EPP endorses digitalization of film heritage and expansion of the Financial Guarantee Facility to boost SME access to €750 million credit lines.  
EPP approves simplified application procedures and enhanced evaluation transparency through detailed rejection feedback mechanisms.  
EPP emphasizes cross-sectoral innovation through improved MEDIA sub-programme coordination with Horizon Europe and structural funds.  
EPP advocates reinforcing European Capitals of Culture as economic catalysts while proposing stricter UNESCO collaboration on heritage protection.

ENF rejects the refugee integration funding as fundamentally doubting with ENF's position against immigrationist policies, denouncing it as an irresponsible burden on European taxpayers.  
ENF opposes budget increases for Creative Europe, condemning the reallocation of 4 million euros to the European Year of Cultural Heritage as a wasteful diversion from core cultural priorities.  
ENF opposes third-country expansions of the programme, insisting limited funds must exclusively support European cultural enterprises rather than global initiatives.  
ENF condemns the issue's failure to explicitly safeguard cultural exceptions in trade agreements, inconsistent with ENF's sovereignty-first principles.  
ENF fundamentally rejects the issue's dilution of cultural priorities through non-essential spending, highlighting its incompatibility with ENF's vision of fiscally disciplined cultural nationalism.

GREEN_EFA completely promotes the issue's demand for increased budgetary allocations to the Creative Europe programme, perfectly aligning with their commitment to recognizing culture's societal value and addressing the current underfunding at 0.15% of the MFR.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on simplifying application processes for small cultural operators, ensuring equitable access to funding and strengthening grassroots cultural initiatives across Europe.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the issue's focus on promoting European cultural diversity and linguistic heritage, which directly advances their priority of fostering egalitarian cultural policies that celebrate minority voices and cross-border cooperation.  

GREEN_EFA fully supports the expansion of cultural integration initiatives for refugees, echoing their call for significantly increased funding beyond the initial 1.6 million to properly address this vital societal challenge.  

GREEN_EFA endorses the issue's recognition of cultural sectors' economic significance, perfectly reflecting their advocacy for positioning creative industries as central components of EU economic policy and investment strategies.

ECR rejects the issue’s premise of a unified European culture as fundamentally inconsistent with their defense of national sovereignty and regional diversity.  
ECR opposes centralized EU cultural governance, citing Germany’s lack of a federal culture minister as proof that subsidiarity must prevail over Brussels-led initiatives.  
ECR challenges the call for increased funding, arguing existing Creative Europe resources should first demonstrate efficiency and avoid bureaucratic redundancy.  
ECR condemns the issue’s imbalance in favoring high-production countries through MEDIA’s automatic points system, which undermines fair competition.  
ECR dismisses the push for expanded cultural integration of refugees as overreach, stressing member states alone should manage such policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the underfunding of the Creative Europe programme, particularly its Culture sub-programme, which has a 15% success rate for applicants compared to 44% for MEDIA, and called for increased budgetary allocations to align with cultural and economic ambitions. It highlighted the programme’s role in promoting European cultural diversity, linguistic heritage, and cross-border cooperation, while noting challenges such as administrative complexity, insufficient financial access for small operators, and imbalances in the MEDIA sub-programme’s automatic points system, which penalizes high-production countries. The resolution emphasized the need to simplify application processes, enhance transparency in project evaluations, and expand support for refugees’ cultural integration through dedicated initiatives. It praised the European Capitals of Culture and Heritage Label for fostering local development and identity, and urged better coordination with UNESCO, the Council of Europe, and OECD to strengthen international cultural relations. Parliament recommended revising the MEDIA sub-programme to improve subtitling, digitize audiovisual heritage, and support competitive European video games, while advocating for a stronger cross-sectoral strand to drive innovation and social inclusion. It stressed the economic significance of cultural sectors, contributing 4.4% of EU GDP and 3.8% of employment, and called for future programme iterations (2021-2028) to prioritize artistic quality, operational grants for networks, and a potential European observatory on culture. Key demands included expanding the Financial Guarantee Facility to boost SME access, balancing economic and artistic criteria in funding decisions, and ensuring equitable geographic distribution of resources to sustain Europe’s global cultural competitiveness.

title: Implementation of the Europe for Citizens programme: REPORT on the implementation of Council Regulation (EU) No 390/2014 of 14 April 2014 establishing the ʻEurope for Citizensʼ programme for the period 2014–2020
background: The Europe for Citizens programme (2014-2020) faced reduced funding under the 2014-2020 MFF, limiting project approvals amid rising Euroscepticism, migration challenges, and calls for enhanced civic participation. The Parliament will discuss the programme’s implementation challenges and strategies to strengthen EU citizenship engagement.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the issue's promotion of eurofederalist cultural uniformity as antithetical to national sovereignty and diversity.  
ENF opposes using taxpayer funds to "combat stigmatization of migrants," citing direct contradiction with public opposition reflected in referendums and polls.  
ENF condemns the program's procedural opacity and underfunding as systemic failures that alienate grassroots organizations and peripheral nations like Romania.  
ENF disputes the issue's premise of "amplifying EU values" through centralized platforms, framing it as propaganda that silences Eurosceptic dissent.  
ENF denounces partnerships with EU agencies like the Education, Audiovisual and Culture Executive Agency as hierarchical mechanisms enforcing ideological compliance.

ALDE strongly agrees the issue's demand to increase the Europe for Citizens programme budget to €500 million, aligning with ALDE's commitment to counter Euroscepticism through robust civic engagement and historical truth-telling.  
ALDE endorses the prioritization of town-twinning initiatives and regional cooperation networks, emphasizing their proven role in fostering grassroots European solidarity as demonstrated by decades of ALDA-led projects.  
ALDE applauds the explicit inclusion of events like the 80th anniversary of the Spanish Civil War in eligible activities, reinforcing their stance on confronting totalitarian legacies and advancing transitional justice frameworks.  
ALDE proposes expanding partnerships with Western Balkan candidate countries through enhanced project co-design mechanisms, reflecting their vision of pre-accession European identity building.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgency of simplifying lump-sum funding procedures to better accommodate small municipalities and civil society organizations, ensuring equitable participation across all regions.

SD strongly accepts the call to increase the Europe for Citizens programme budget to €500 million, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to amplifying citizen-driven EU initiatives and countering Euroscepticism through meaningful engagement.  
SD approves the demand for Parliament’s co-legislative authority over the programme, emphasizing that this institutional parity is critical to ensuring democratic accountability in line with SD’s principles.  
SD highlights the need to simplify application procedures as a key enhancement opportunity, proposing concrete amendments to prioritize small organizations and marginalized groups through tailored funding mechanisms.  
SD applauds the issue’s focus on digital communication strategies, urging the inclusion of youth-centric platforms and social media campaigns to effectively advance SD’s priority of fostering civic participation among younger generations.  
SD endorses the emphasis on addressing contemporary challenges like migration and social inclusion, recommending explicit integration of these themes into town-twinning projects to strengthen pan-European solidarity.

ECR rejects the programme's artificial identity construction as inconsistent with traditional values, noting the issue's omission of Europe's Judeo-Christian foundations.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the paternalistic "Europe for Citizens" model that imposes elite-driven narratives rather than empowering national democratic processes.  
ECR condemns the programme's budget expansion demands as contradictory to fiscal responsibility and subsidiarity principles, given its proven inefficiency in addressing real economic hardships.  
ECR disputes the issue's centralization agenda through "synergies" with EU programmes, which undermines national sovereignty in cultural and civic matters.  
ECR highlights the proposal's failure to address grassroots democratic deficits, mirroring EU-wide distrust in top-down "citizen engagement" mechanisms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the underfunding and implementation challenges of the Europe for Citizens (EfC) Programme 2014-2020, which aims to promote European remembrance, democratic engagement, and civic participation through two strands: "European Remembrance" (fostering awareness of shared history and values) and "Democratic Engagement and Civic Participation" (encouraging citizen involvement in EU policymaking). Despite its symbolic importance, the programme’s budget of €185.47 million (0.0171% of the Multiannual Financial Framework) was deemed insufficient, with a 13.7% cut leading to a 25% reduction in funded projects by 2014 and a mere 6% success rate for remembrance and civil society projects in 2015, compared to higher rates in other programmes like Creative Europe. The Parliament highlighted the programme’s impact, including 1.1 million participants in 408 projects in 2015, but stressed that limited funding caused frustration among applicants and hindered goals. It called for a budget increase to €500 million (€1 per citizen) in the next MFF, simplified procedures, enhanced synergies with programmes like Erasmus+ and Creative Europe, and improved communication through a centralized online platform. Recommendations included prioritizing town-twinning initiatives, addressing contemporary challenges (migration, radicalization, social inclusion), ensuring accessibility for marginalized groups, and formalizing multiannual priorities. The resolution also urged legal reforms to grant Parliament co-legislative authority over the programme, criticized the lump-sum funding system for disadvantaging smaller organizations and regions with higher costs, and emphasized the need for transparent feedback on rejected applications. Additionally, it advocated for greater international participation, including EFTA and candidate countries, and leveraging social media to amplify outreach and promote EU values amid rising Euroscepticism.

title: European Solidarity Corps programme: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Solidarity Corps programme and repealing [European Solidarity Corps Regulation] and Regulation (EU) No 375/2014
background: The European Solidarity Corps, initiated in 2016, aimed to foster youth engagement in volunteering and solidarity activities. Existing EU programmes, including the EU Aid Volunteers, operated separately, prompting calls for consolidation. The Commission proposed integrating these under a unified framework with expanded objectives and funding. The Parliament will discuss establishing a revised ESC programme to harmonise implementation, enhance accessibility, and address societal needs.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly upholds the issue's ambitious budget expansion to 1.2 billion euros, which aligns perfectly with GREEN_EFA's longstanding commitment to scaling youth-driven solidarity as a cornerstone of EU cohesion.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the emphasis on empowering young people through transnational volunteering, recognizing how initiatives like climate action and migrant support directly advance GREEN_EFA's priority of fostering empathetic, civically engaged generations.  
The issue effectively advances GREEN_EFA's vision by mandating robust learning outcomes and restricting traineeships to non-profit tasks, ensuring participants gain transformative skills without commercial exploitation.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the binding inclusivity measures—particularly part-time opportunities for disadvantaged youth—as a critical step toward equitable access, reflecting their 2023 manifesto pledge to dismantle barriers in EU mobility programs.  
By integrating targeted outreach in remote areas and ESC ambassadors, the proposal operationalizes GREEN_EFA's principle that solidarity must actively bridge geographic and socioeconomic divides to strengthen collective European identity.

SD firmly upholds the issue's emphasis on transnationally focused solidarity activities, perfectly aligning with S&D's vision of building pan-European civic identity through youth engagement.  
SD perfectly aligns with the differentiated quality label system, recognizing its capacity to maintain high standards while expanding opportunities in social enterprises and non-profit sectors.  
SD firmly upholds mandatory inclusion outcome reporting, seeing this as critical to realizing the program's promise of accessibility for youth with disabilities and marginalized backgrounds.  
SD strongly promotes the issue's definition of solidarity as "responsibility for the common good," which operationalizes S&D's principle of collective social action through concrete volunteering frameworks.  
SD applauds the integration of humanitarian aid without age limits, effectively advancing S&D's commitment to intergenerational solidarity in climate-related crisis response.

ECR fully disapproves with the proposal’s allocation of €1.2 billion to paid volunteering, arguing this contradicts the principle of unpaid solidarity and misdirects funds from youth employment initiatives.  
ECR rejects the issue’s reliance on NGOs for refugee-related activities, citing concerns over accountability and inefficiency in current practices.  
ECR highlights that defining paid placements as “volunteering” undermines traditional solidarity values and risks institutionalizing dependency.  
ECR calls for reallocating ESC funds to direct job creation programs, asserting the proposal fails to address systemic youth unemployment.  
ECR opposes expanding in-country activities, arguing remote outreach efforts inadequately prevent misuse of resources in migration management.

GUE_NGL fundamentally rejects the proposal's neoliberal framing of solidarity as a tool for youth employability, which dangerously conflates civic engagement with precarious labor market integration.  
GUE_NGL opposes the inclusion of profit-driven entities in ESC activities, as this directly contradicts anti-capitalist principles and risks commodifying social justice initiatives.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of youth empowerment by prioritizing corporate-aligned "entrepreneurship" over guaranteed access to education, dignified work, and public service opportunities.  
GUE_NGL condemns the program's ideological distortion of solidarity into a mechanism to normalize austerity-driven policies that exacerbate the very crises it claims to address.  
This proposal is inconsistent with GUE_NGL's demand for systemic change, as it fails to challenge the neoliberal EU structures creating unemployment and humanitarian crises.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to enhance the European Solidarity Corps (ESC) by streamlining processes and expanding outreach, aiming for over 350,000 placements over seven years through improved communication strategies, including social media campaigns, ESC ambassadors, and targeted outreach in remote areas. Key measures include establishing a unified application system via e-forms and a single branding approach to simplify access and reduce administrative costs, alongside differentiated quality labels for organizations based on activity type to ensure high standards. The resolution emphasized inclusivity by proposing part-time opportunities for disadvantaged youth, limiting in-country activities to projects with strong inclusion objectives, and mandating feedback on inclusion outcomes. It stressed aligning ESC activities with societal needs, particularly social inclusion and humanitarian challenges, and integrating a robust learning component in jobs and traineeships, restricted to non-profit tasks. The Parliament advocated adopting work programmes through delegated acts to ensure co-legislator oversight, defining "solidarity" and "volunteering" to unify program implementation, and fostering long-term civic engagement. Participants are to receive advance learning outcome details and meaningful feedback to maximize personal growth, while stakeholders, including youth networks, should be regularly consulted to strengthen program relevance and impact.

title: Follow-up of the Strategic Framework for European cooperation in education and training (ET2020): REPORT on follow-up of the Strategic Framework for European cooperation in education and training (ET2020)
background: The ET2020 framework, established in 2009 to advance EU education cooperation, underwent evaluations in 2012 and 2015 identifying persistent challenges including migration pressures, refugee influx, economic disparities, and systemic gaps in education quality, inclusion, and teacher preparedness. The Parliament will discuss strategies to strengthen European education and training collaboration under ET2020.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the emphasis on teacher training and professional development, aligning with the issue’s call for improved working conditions and Erasmus+ as a key tool for educator mobility.  
EPP completely sanctions the focus on education as a value beyond labor-market outcomes, particularly the integration of ethics, social-emotional learning, and anti-radicalization curricula to foster cohesive societies.  
EPP approves the balanced approach to migrant integration through language support and inclusive curricula, reinforcing intercultural dialogue as critical to EU stability.  
EPP proposes enhancing Erasmus+ to specifically address cross-border teacher training collaborations, ensuring pedagogical innovations align with digital competency goals.  
EPP applauds the issue’s recognition of subsidiarity, which aligns with EPP’s principle of respecting national education systems while advancing shared EU quality benchmarks.

ENF rejects the issue's migrant integration clauses as culturally disruptive to European equilibrium  
ENF opposes fundamentally Brussels' educational standardization violating national sovereignty in teaching methods  
This entirely conflicts with ENF's position that EU austerity policies directly harm teacher welfare despite rhetorical support  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as prioritizing education partnerships in conflict zones over internal migrant schooling  
ENF demands treaty reforms to halt migration-driven educational burdens before addressing existing East-West skill disparities

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to prioritize refugee integration, firmly disapproveing with their commitment to inclusive education by omitting concrete measures for asylum seekers' language support and qualification recognition.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the economic reductionism in the framework, which contradicts their principle that education must foster intercultural dialogue and democratic citizenship beyond labor-market utilitarianism.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the inadequate treatment of early school leaving and digital competencies, as the issue substitutes actionable solutions with vague aspirations inconsistent with urgent equity imperatives.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the issue's strategic timidity on preschool education and lifelong learning, noting its alignment with national coordination over bold European added value they demand.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the superficial engagement with radicalization prevention, asserting that the report ignores structural educational poverty drivers central to their social justice agenda.

ALDE strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on cross-border cooperation and exchange of best practices, which aligns perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to fostering transparent, inclusive education systems that address diverse learner needs.  
ALDE approves the focus on innovative teaching methods and adult learning modernization, proposing to enhance monitoring mechanisms to ensure these strategies prioritize student creativity and active participation in line with digital transformation goals.  
ALDE strongly endorses the urgency of integrating migrants and refugees through qualification recognition and language support, urging faster EU-national coordination to align these efforts with labor market demands and social cohesion objectives.  
ALDE highlights the need to amplify local and regional authorities’ roles in managing educational institutions, particularly in implementing mobility programs like Euroodiseja, to strengthen youth employability and intercultural exchange.  
ALDE proposes reinforcing early childhood education investments as a complementary measure to adult learning reforms, ensuring lifelong learning frameworks address both current and future demographic challenges.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined priorities for enhancing education and training systems under the ET2020 framework, emphasizing inclusive, high-quality education as a fundamental right and public good essential for social cohesion, economic growth, and democratic values. It stressed the need to address persistent challenges such as educational poverty, socio-economic disparities, low adult learning participation, early school leaving (targeting a reduction below 10%), and insufficient digital and basic skills. The resolution advocated for improved teacher training, better working conditions, and higher salaries to attract and retain qualified educators, while promoting innovative pedagogies and ICT integration, including digital competencies and open educational resources. It highlighted the urgency of integrating migrants, refugees, and asylum seekers through language support, recognition of qualifications, and inclusive curricula, alongside measures to counter radicalization and foster intercultural dialogue. The Parliament called for balanced investment in STEM and humanities disciplines, cautioning against overemphasis on labor-market outcomes at the expense of critical thinking, creativity, and ethical values. It endorsed the Europe 2020 target of 40% tertiary education attainment but urged quality assurance, dual education models, and validation of non-formal learning. Additional priorities included addressing brain drain, enhancing mobility programs like Erasmus+, and mainstreaming gender equality to close gaps in access and outcomes. The resolution urged Member States to leverage EU funding tools, improve policy coordination, and share best practices to achieve these goals while respecting national competencies and regional diversity.

title: Language equality in the digital age: REPORT on language equality in the digital age
background: The European Union's multilingual framework, encompassing 24 official and over 60 regional, minority, and sign languages, faces challenges in digital adaptation amid increasing reliance on language-dependent technologies. Existing EU policies on digital integration and cultural diversity, alongside studies highlighting risks of digital language exclusion, inform this issue. The Parliament will discuss measures to address disparities in technological support for linguistic diversity within digital environments.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly agrees the issue's emphasis on linguistic diversity as a core European value, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to cultural heritage and minority rights.  
EPP proposes strengthening legal frameworks to ensure comprehensive protection for regional and minority languages in digital spaces, addressing member states' inconsistent implementation efforts.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for EU-funded AI-driven language technologies, urging immediate adoption of the "European Native Languages Project" to secure global leadership in language preservation.  
EPP emphasizes enhancing accessibility of all EU institutional websites in 24 official languages, transforming current gaps into opportunities for inclusive digital governance.  
EPP fully supports prioritizing Horizon Europe funding for interoperable translation tools, viewing this as critical to eliminating SME barriers in the Digital Single Market.

ENF rejects the issue's interference in member states' exclusive competence over national education systems and linguistic strategies.  
ENF opposes fundamentally the conflation of "migrant languages" with European minority languages, citing Article 4(2) TEU protections for national identity.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the EU's own institutional dominance of English post-Brexit, undermining its credibility to dictate language policies.  
This absolutely againsts with ENF's position that language acquisition—not technological substitution—must remain central to preserving cultural heritage.  
 ENF highlights the issue's failure to address subsidiarity violations in mandating bilingual education frameworks.

ECR supports the issue's emphasis on linguistic diversity but advises expanding Article 4 to mandate dedicated funding streams for AI-driven tools tailored to smaller EU sign languages.  
ECR endorses cross-border e-commerce accessibility goals but recommends amending Annex II to include standardized sign language video interfaces for public e-services.  
ECR agrees with cloud platform interoperability but urges specifying compatibility requirements for regional sign language recognition technologies in Section 3.2.  
ECR welcomes minority language protections but proposes adding a clause to fund collaborative R&D projects between deaf communities and LT developers.  
ECR acknowledges digital literacy initiatives but suggests integrating sign language-specific metrics into the Horizon Europe monitoring framework.

GUE_NGL strongly advocates the issue’s prioritization of combating digital language extinction, aligning perfectly with GUE_NGL's longstanding commitment to linguistic rights and anti-imperialist cultural sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL applauds the call for EU-funded language technologies as critical to reversing Galician’s underrepresentation in digital spaces, matching their manifesto demands for technological equity.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the urgency of cloud-based translation tools to empower SMEs in regions like Galicia, where cross-border commerce is stifled by linguistic marginalization.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending the issue to explicitly frame “minority” languages as historically oppressed languages, rejecting state-centric terminology that erases colonial impositions.  
GUE_NGL urges immediate implementation of parliamentary language facilities to enable full expression in all EU languages, ensuring digital equality mirrors institutional practice.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the growing digital language divide threatening Europe’s linguistic diversity, noting over 60 regional, minority, and sign languages alongside 24 official EU languages, with more than 20 facing "digital extinction" due to insufficient technological resources. It emphasized the urgent need to address language barriers hindering cross-border e-commerce (only 16% in 2015) and the fragmented Digital Single Market, urging the EU to prioritize multilingualism through coordinated policies, funding, and research. Key recommendations included establishing large-scale funding programs for language technologies (LTs), particularly AI-driven solutions like deep learning, to ensure equal access for lesser-used languages, support SMEs with automated translation tools, and promote cloud-based, interoperable platforms. The resolution stressed the EU’s responsibility to reduce inequalities by developing multilingual public e-services, enhancing digital literacy in minority languages, and fostering collaboration between academia, industry, and governments. It called for a dedicated EU strategy to preserve linguistic diversity, including financial support for subtitling, translation tools, and keyboard layouts for endangered languages, while emphasizing the cultural and economic benefits of a multilingual digital ecosystem aligned with Horizon 2020 and future research frameworks.

title: Learning EU at school: REPORT on Learning EU at school
background: Persistent citizen engagement challenges, including low EU knowledge levels in Eurobarometer surveys and declining youth voter turnout in European elections, alongside disparities in national education systems' integration of EU-related content, prompted scrutiny. The Parliament will discuss strategies to enhance EU awareness and civic education within member states' school curricula.

stances.stance:
EPP totally accepts the issue's focus on continuous teacher training and digital tools, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to equipping educators with EU-related competencies through Erasmus+ and e-learning platforms.  
EPP perfectly aligns with integrating EU civic education into national curricula, recognizing its critical role in fostering active citizenship and social cohesion as emphasized in Articles 2 TEU.  
EPP fully supports enhancing EU institutional literacy in schools, directly addressing the 44% knowledge gap identified by Eurobarometer and countering Euroscepticism through informed citizenry.  
EPP totally accepts multilingualism and Erasmus+ mobility programs, reflecting the issue's prioritization of intercultural dialogue and non-formal learning for European identity-building.  
EPP perfectly aligns with early-stage EU civic education using interactive methods, advancing the issue's goal of embedding digital tools and shared historical narratives in curricula.

EFDD requests revising Article 2 TEU alignment to exclude federalist interpretations, citing risks of ideological indoctrination inconsistent with subsidiarity.  
This completely againsts with EFDD’s opposition to centralised EU curricula, proposing instead member-state autonomy in teaching critical EU assessments.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as EU democratic deficits in decision-making processes, requiring explicit curriculum modules on Commission accountability gaps.  
EFDD rejects the issue’s reliance on EU-funded programs like Jean Monnet, urging amendments to prohibit Brussels-led pedagogical frameworks in schools.

ENF rejects the issue's approach to counter Euroscepticism through education, viewing it as ideological suppression that completely challenges with ENF's defense of national sovereignty and pluralism.  
ENF opposes the proposed EU-centric curricula as propaganda, arguing it prioritizes political indoctrination over core academic competencies like literacy and mathematics.  
ENF fundamentally rejects the harmonization of Member States' education systems, denouncing it as an unlawful overreach into national competencies protected by EU treaties.  
ENF condemns the issue's emphasis on multiculturalism and EU narratives, asserting it undermines national identities and fails to address citizens' rejection of centralized EU societal models.  
ENF opposes the use of EU-funded programs like Erasmus+ and Jean Monnet projects as tools to impose a federalist agenda, which directly contradicts ENF's principles of preserving Europe's sovereign nation-states.

SD strongly advocates the integration of a European dimension into school curricula, aligning perfectly with S&D’s longstanding commitment to fostering active citizenship and democratic engagement through education.  
SD applauds the emphasis on harmonizing vocational and technical education programs across member states, proposing enhanced focus on agricultural education to address rural development challenges as a strategic enhancement opportunity.  
SD approves the issue’s call for leveraging Erasmus+ and Jean Monnet initiatives, which effectively advance S&D’s priority of equipping educators with EU-related competencies and promoting mobility.  
SD endorses the push for a standardized EU curriculum to deepen youth understanding of institutional mechanisms, strongly matching S&D’s manifesto goals to combat Euroscepticism through informed civic participation.  
SD emphasizes the need for robust EU-funded information campaigns to popularize citizens’ rights, reinforcing the issue’s aim to strengthen trust in European institutions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical need to integrate a European dimension into education systems to foster active citizenship, mutual understanding, and democratic engagement, addressing challenges such as low voter turnout (42.61% in the 2014 EU elections, with only 27.8% among 18-24 year-olds) and citizens’ limited understanding of EU mechanisms (44% feel inadequately informed, 52% believe their voice does not count). Emphasizing the role of education in promoting EU values under Article 2 TEU, the resolution called for curricula reforms to include EU history, governance, and decision-making processes, using interactive and digital tools, while strengthening teacher training and mobility programs like Erasmus+ to enhance educators’ EU-related competencies. It urged Member States to ensure inclusive, non-discriminatory education, support multilingualism, and leverage EU-funded initiatives such as the Jean Monnet projects, eTwinning, and the Europe for Citizens programme to deepen civic participation. The resolution highlighted the importance of non-formal learning, youth engagement, and intercultural dialogue, advocating for validation of informal learning outcomes and closer collaboration between schools, civil society, and EU institutions. It also stressed the need for increased investment in education, equitable access to quality learning, and the development of platforms like the House of European History to promote a shared narrative of European integration, aiming to counter Euroscepticism and strengthen democratic legitimacy through informed, critical citizenry.

title: Motions for resolutions - Expo Milano 2015: Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Milano Expo 2015: Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life
background: The International Exhibitions Bureau designated Milan to host the 2015 Universal Exposition on global food systems, coinciding with FAO reports on agricultural projections and UN sustainability goals. The Parliament will discuss strategies addressing global food security, sustainable agriculture, and nutrition challenges in the context of population growth and resource constraints.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the issue's failure to prevent corporate dominance at Expo 2015, directly conflicting with their commitment to empowering small-scale producers and transparent agricultural governance.  
EFDD opposes the Milan Charter's omission of financial speculation on commodities and land grabbing, which undermines equitable resource access central to EFDD's food security principles.  
EFDD fundamentally againsts with the issue's alignment with EU policies restricting GM crops and neonicotinoids without field evidence, contradicting their advocacy for science-driven agricultural innovation.  
EFDD rejects the issue's tacit acceptance of land degradation exemplified by Expo's conversion of fertile land, opposing EFDD's mandate to protect soil integrity and local farming economies.  
EFDD opposes the issue's endorsement of sponsors engaged in greenwashing, which violates EFDD's demand for authentic sustainability over corporate-driven agendas.

ALDE approves the binding targets to reduce food waste, highlighting their alignment with ALDE’s advocacy for resource efficiency and circular economy principles, while urging faster adoption of waste-tracking technologies.  
ALDE endorses the focus on small-scale farming and local food systems, emphasizing that protecting traditional practices and SMEs is critical to preserving Europe’s culinary heritage and ensuring equitable market access.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgency of addressing global food-price imbalances, advocating for trade policies that prioritize affordability without compromising quality, as raised in debates on antibiotic use and nutritional equity.  
ALDE applauds the integration of climate action into food security strategies, urging explicit linkage to the Paris Agreement’s mitigation mechanisms to strengthen supply chain resilience.

SD strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on binding targets to combat food waste, aligning with SD's commitment to halve EU food waste by 2030 through improved supply chain efficiency and consumer education.  
SD absolutely approves leveraging the Milan Charter to institutionalize the right to food as a fundamental human right, particularly its focus on empowering smallholder farmers who form 70% of agricultural workers in developing nations.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 23 by explicitly linking corporate tax enforcement to reduced food prices, ensuring multinational agribusinesses contribute equitably to social safety nets addressing malnutrition.  
SD applauds the issue's integration of climate action with agricultural policy, particularly its alignment with Paris Agreement goals to combat land degradation through agroecological practices.  
SD urges strengthening provisions on women's empowerment in farming by mandating gender-disaggregated data collection for all EU-funded agricultural development programs.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue's emphasis on agricultural intensification, entirely rejecting with their demand for systemic transition to plant-based food systems and reduction of industrial livestock farming.  
GUE/NGL opposes the legitimization of corporate-driven food policies, as the issue fails to condemn partnerships with Coca-Cola and McDonald’s, which perpetuate globalized food inequities.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue’s silence on Expo Milano’s corruption scandals and labor exploitation, directly contradicting their anti-capitalist and anti-mafia principles.  
GUE/NGL disputes the issue’s reliance on EU agricultural subsidies, advocating instead for abolishing policies that prioritize agribusiness over small-scale agroecological practices.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical need to address global food security, nutrition, and sustainable agriculture through the Milan Expo 2015 theme "Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life," emphasizing the paradox of 870 million undernourished people alongside 2.8 million deaths linked to obesity and poor diets. resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the Commission’s decision to discontinue direct funding for Euranet Plus, a pan-European radio network comprising 13 public and private broadcasters across 13 Member States, reaching over 15 million daily listeners and providing EU-related content in 12 languages. It emphasized Euranet Plus’s unique role in bridging the information gap on EU policies, promoting media diversity, and supporting minority languages, while meeting the Financial Regulation’s criteria for specific operational needs. The resolution criticized the Commission’s shift to competitive annual calls for proposals starting in 2021, arguing this abrupt change—without transitional measures or prior strategic dialogue—jeopardizes the network’s sustainability, risks liquidation, and undermines its ability to plan for digital transition and service improvements. Parliament urged the Commission to renew core funding via a two-year transitional grant (€2.16 million annually) to allow Euranet Plus to develop a strategic plan until 2027, expand membership, and prepare for digitalization. It demanded reallocation of the €2.2 million earmarked for 2022 radio broadcasting directly to Euranet Plus, bypassing open calls, and called for an interinstitutional working group involving DG CONNECT, DG BUDG, and the CULT Committee to establish a multiannual funding framework. The resolution stressed that sustained support aligns with EU public interest, ensuring cost-efficiency and continuity, whereas short-term funding models impose administrative burdens and destabilize beneficiaries.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the critical need to strengthen citizenship education across the EU to address democratic deficits, misinformation, and societal polarization, emphasizing its role in fostering active, informed civic participation and countering threats like radicalization and Euroscepticism. EU programs like Erasmus+ allocated only 0.000046% of its 2014-2020 budget to citizenship education projects, while Horizon Europe and Creative Europe dedicated 0.00002% and 0.000007%, respectively, with limited geographical reach and sustainability. Member states’ citizenship education varies widely, with curricula often prioritizing national over European dimensions and facing politicization in countries like Poland and Hungary. Teacher training and assessment methods remain inconsistent, with half of EU countries lacking regulations for educators. The 2016 ICCS study revealed only 35% of students had holistic civic knowledge, though 83% learned about European history, and higher civic knowledge correlated with trust in EU institutions (70% trusted the EU, 72% the Parliament). The resolution urged systemic reforms to integrate citizenship education across formal and lifelong learning, stressing the need for inclusive, participatory approaches to sustain democratic resilience.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the severe impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the cultural and creative sectors (CCS), which suffered cumulative losses of €199 billion in 2020, with music and performing arts sectors losing 75% and 90% of revenue respectively. It highlighted the CCS’s vital economic role, contributing 4-7% of EU GDP and 8.7 million jobs, while emphasizing their social value in fostering democracy, mental health, and cultural diversity. The resolution urged structural reforms, including a proposed *European Status of the Artist* to harmonize working conditions, social protections (e.g., pensions, healthcare), and tax deductions for cultural professionals, addressing precarious employment affecting 33% of self-employed workers. It called for allocating at least 2% of the Recovery and Resilience Facility to CCS recovery, integrating them into EU funding programs like InvestEU and Creative Europe, and simplifying cross-border mobility by reducing bureaucratic barriers. The Parliament stressed enforcing copyright reforms (Directive 2019/790) to ensure fair remuneration, promoting collective bargaining, and combating gender inequality, discrimination, and barriers faced by marginalized groups. It advocated for digital innovation, sustainable practices, and improved data collection to monitor CCS vulnerabilities, urging Member States to prioritize cultural spaces’ reopening, enhance vocational training, and safeguard artistic freedom against political interference.
